_prev_prog_3.Description: This process includes an ammonia refrigeration systems, which is a standard compression and evaporation style system. Process Safety Management and Risk Management Plans have been implemeted.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sugar Creek Packing is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program Regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.

Sugar Creek Packing is located at 1241 North Gettysburg Avenue, Dayton Ohio 45427. We are a Bacon producing facility.  The facility includes processing tanks, piping, warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage. Ammonia refrigeration engine rooms and, miscellaneous utilities.
 
The refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan.  The refrigeration system contains of 26,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.

Sugar Creek Packing has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.

Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and, accepted by all employees at our facility.  Our facility management believes in the importance of work place safety and are empowered to enforce all of our company policies

.

Sugar Creek Packing has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library consisting of nine volumes. 

Volume I of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates mainly policies, the following policies are included in Volume I: Volume I covers Plant 1 and Plant 2.

Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.

Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR Ammonia Data Book).

Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.

Employee Training Program: This program provides employees with a basic working knowledge of an ammonia refrigeration system.  Areas covered are hazards of ammonia, understanding MSDS sheets, refrigeration cycles, normal system operation, emergency system operation, and an individuals place in the emergency response plan.

Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.

Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.

Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Plant Safety Coordinator.

TEM II

Volume II (System II) incorporates information on the specific system components of the production area equipment (Compressors, purgers, vessels, heat exchangers, evaporators, condensers, pumps, piping systems, the emergency ventilation system, safety relief valves, and general safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components, ordering of spare parts, troubleshooting, and system optimization is improved due to the information contained in this manual.
 
Volume III (System II) incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawings pertinent to the production area equipment.

The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.

Flow schematics are included showing the entire system.

A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system.

Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.

Volume IV (System II) incorporates a complete set of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the ammonia refrigeration system equipment. These SOPs describe the proper steps for preparing components for start-up and starting components.  Monitoring normal operation of system components.  Shutting down components as part of normal operation and restarting equipment as part of normal operation.  Shutting down equipment for maintenance and restarting equipment after maintenance.  Shutting down equipment in emergency situations and restarting equipment after an emergency situation shutdown.  SOPs also discuss pump out procedures for equipment. Also included, as a part of each SOP, are the Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) for the associate system component. This information includes consequences of

deviation from standard operating procedures.

ASSOCIATED POLICIES See Volume 1, of Sugar Creek Packing Company PSM/RMP Program

All operators working on the refrigeration system must be trained via the Employee Training Program.
Plant Lockout/Tagout Program shall be followed when taking unit or system out of service, maintaining, and returning equipment to service.
Proper Personal Protective Equipment shall be worn whenever performing

any operation, which may lead to a release of either ammonia liquid or vapor. Plant requirements dictate standard personal protective equipment for all maintenance employees and contractors.
Hot Work Permit program shall be followed when taking unit or system out of service, maintaining, and returning equipment to service.
The ?Policy for Opening the Refrigeration System? shall be used when opening the refrigeration system.
A Management of Change program shall be followed when any change is made to the Ammonia Refrigeration system. 
All contractors working on the refrigeration system must be approved via the Contractor?s Qualification Program. 
There are numerous other policies, which affect the safety of plant employees and the welfare of the refrigeration system. All Company Policies are to be adhered to when performing  work on the refrigeration system.

SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No injuries associated with the ammonia refrigeration system in the last 5 years.

DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

An Emergency Planning and Response Program has been established to allow for safe mitigation of any ammonia release. An emergency response team has been formed, trained and equipped to handle most chemical emergencies at the facility. Our response plan has been coordinated with the Dayton Hazmat. This program is in the process of being revamped to train and certify in house responders to help and train with the Dayton Hazmat Team.

CONCLUSION

Sugar Creek Packing is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Sugar Creek Packing to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
